Question Text: Which of the following properties are characteristics of virtual networks (but not necessarily characteristics of SDN). Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Separates the data and control plane.
b. Refactors network control so that network behavior is controlled from a single logically centralized controller.
c. Separates logical and physical networks.
d. Often deployed in data center networks to allow multiple tenants to share physical network infrastructure.
e. Abstracts the details of the physical network.
LLM Explanation: Virtual networks have the following key characteristics:  c) They separate the logical network topology from the underlying physical network infrastructure. Multiple virtual networks can be overlaid on the same physical network.  d) They are commonly used in multi-tenant data center environments to allow different tenants (customers) to share the same physical network hardware while keeping their traffic isolated. Each tenant gets their own virtual network.  e) The virtual network abstracts away the details and complexity of the physical network from the perspective of the virtual network user or tenant. The virtual network presents a simplified logical topology.  While virtual networks and SDN are related concepts that are often used together, properties (a) and (b) are more specific to SDN. Separation of data and control planes and logically centralized control are key tenets of SDN but not necessarily virtual networks in general.

Question Text: Which of the following are possible ways of creating virtual links in a virtual network? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. A wide-area tunnel, whereby an IP packet is encapsulated in an MPLS tunnel by attaching an MPLS header to the packet.
b. Longest-prefix match forwarding on an IP router.
c. A wide-area tunnel, whereby an Ethernet packet sent between two virtual machines is encapsulated in an IP packet.
d. VLAN switching based on a VLAN tag.
e. Pairs of virtual Ethernet interfaces, where one end of the Ethernet interface pair resides in the virtual environment, and the other resides in the root namespace on the host machine.
LLM Explanation: Virtual links in a virtual network can be created in several ways. Encapsulating IP packets in MPLS tunnels (a) or Ethernet packets in IP tunnels (c) enables virtual links across wide-area networks. VLAN switching based on tags (d) allows virtual links on the same physical network. Virtual Ethernet interface pairs (e) create virtual links between VMs and the host. Longest-prefix match forwarding (b) is a regular IP routing mechanism, not specifically for creating virtual links.
URLs: ['Software Defined Networks: A Comprehensive Approach by Paul Goransson and Chuck Black, Chapter 5', 'Network Virtualization by Victor Moreno and Kumar Reddy, Chapter 3', 'https://www.sdxcentral.com/networking/virtualization/definitions/what-is-network-virtualization/']

Question Text: Which of the following are true of the Mininet network emulator? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. It requires running OpenFlow-capable switches.
b. It is difficult to use it to route traffic for real services.
c. Mininet only allows users to create three types of topologies: linear, tree, and single-switch topologies.
d. It can create an emulation that runs across multiple physically distributed nodes.
e. All of the hosts in the topology must run the same underlying operating system.
LLM Explanation: Mininet does not require running OpenFlow-capable switches, as it can emulate OpenFlow switches in software. It is difficult to use Mininet to route traffic for real services because the emulated network is contained within a single machine and has limited connectivity to the outside world. Mininet allows users to create arbitrary network topologies, not just linear, tree, and single-switch topologies. While Mininet can create an emulation that runs on a single machine, it cannot distribute the emulation across multiple physically distributed nodes. All hosts in a Mininet topology run the same underlying operating system as the machine running the emulation.

Question Text: What are the benefits of emulation as opposed to, say, simulation? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. An emulation will complete faster than a simulation.
b. An emulator makes it possible to "port" experiments from one machine to another.
c. An emulator allows the experimenter run real software on each of the nodes in the emulation.
d. An emulation is easier to debug than a simulation.
e. Every run of the emulator will yield exactly the same results, resulting in reproducible experiments.
LLM Explanation: The key benefits of emulation over simulation are:b) An emulator allows experiments to be 'ported' or moved from one physical machine to another. This is because the emulator abstracts the underlying hardware, making the emulation platform-independent.  c) In an emulation, real software can be run on each emulated node. This allows testing and experimentation with actual applications and operating systems, providing a more realistic environment.Emulation is not necessarily faster than simulation (a), may not be easier to debug (d), and does not guarantee deterministic results across runs (e) as those depend on the emulated software's behavior.

Question Text: Which of the following are possible in Mininet? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Measuring the latency between a host in San Francisco and a host in Los Angeles.
b. Assigning custom IP addresses to each node in the topology.
c. Assigning IP addresses to each node in the topology using a DHCP server.
d. Running performance measurement tools (e.g., iperf, wget) between nodes.
e. "Shaping" a link between two nodes to a particular traffic rate.
LLM Explanation: In Mininet, it is possible to assign custom IP addresses to each node in the topology (b), run performance measurement tools like iperf and wget between nodes (d), and shape the link between two nodes to a particular traffic rate (e). However, measuring latency between geographically distant hosts (a) is not feasible in Mininet as it emulates a network on a single machine. Mininet also does not have a built-in DHCP server to assign IP addresses (c), but static IP assignment is supported.

Question Text: Which of the following functions does FlowVisor enable? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Allowing two different researchers to implement and deploy different load balancing applications for all traffic between the same source-destination pair.
b. Allowing two controllers to control traffic on distinct VLANs.
c. Allowing two different researchers to implement and deploy different Web load balancing applications for port 80 traffic.
d. Allowing two different researchers to implement and deploy control mechanisms for two distinct applications.
e. Allowing one controller to control TCP traffic and one controller to control UDP traffic.
LLM Explanation: FlowVisor enables network virtualization by allowing multiple controllers to manage different slices of the network based on various criteria. It can slice the network based on VLANs (b), allowing different controllers for distinct applications (d), and based on traffic type like TCP vs UDP (e). However, it cannot allow two controllers to manage the same traffic between a source-destination pair (a) or the same application traffic on a specific port (c) as that would lead to conflicts.

Question Text: Which of the following are stated applications of the Nicira Network Virtualization Platform? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Easier transition to IPv6 in data-center networks.
b. Creating more than 1024 virtual networks, as opposed to the alternative of using VLAN tags.
c. Allowing experimental protocols to coincide with a production network.
d. Central management of security policies.
e. Dynamic workload placement in multi-tenant data centers.
LLM Explanation: The Nicira Network Virtualization Platform enables several key applications in data centers and cloud environments:b) It allows creating more than the 4096 virtual networks limit imposed by VLAN tags. This enables much greater network segmentation.c) It can support experimental protocols to run alongside production traffic by isolating them in separate virtual networks. This enables testing new protocols without impacting the main network. d) The platform provides a central point to define and manage security policies across the virtual networks. This simplifies security management.e) In multi-tenant data centers, it allows dynamic placement of workloads by abstracting the network topology from the physical infrastructure. VMs can be moved while preserving their addresses and policies.While it may help in IPv6 transition (a), this is not a commonly stated application of the Nicira platform based on the information provided.
URLs: ['Koponen, Teemu, et al. "Network virtualization in multi-tenant datacenters." 11th USENIX Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation (NSDI 14). 2014.', 'Casado, Martin, et al. "Virtualizing the network forwarding plane." Proceedings of the Workshop on Programmable Routers for Extensible Services of Tomorrow. 2010.']

Question Text: Select the statement that is most true about the relationship between network virtualization and SDNs.
Choices:
a. Network virtualization is a potential enabler for software-defined networks, since the separation of data and control planes first requires the creation of a logical network.
b. Software-defined networking is a potential enabler for virtual networks, since separation of data and control planes makes it easier to manage a logical network topology.
c. Network virtualization is a new concept introduced by Amazon, Nicira, and industry players; it only made sense to talk about network virtualization once central SDN controllers existed.
d. Network virtualization and software-defined networking each enable the other: SDN cannot exist without network virtualization, and network virtualization cannot exist without SDN.
LLM Explanation: Both statements a and b are true about the relationship between network virtualization and SDNs. Network virtualization enables the creation of logical networks separate from the underlying physical infrastructure, which is a prerequisite for separating the data and control planes in SDNs. At the same time, the separation of data and control planes in SDNs makes it easier to manage and orchestrate virtual network topologies. So network virtualization and SDN are complementary technologies that enable each other, rather than one being strictly dependent on the other.
